title: 108_hr4915
content: The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" is cited as the Act. It introduces an exclusion for gains from stock of small, publicly traded companies in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gains from the sale of section 1203 stock held for over 1 year, with a limit of $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately). 1203 stock refers to stock in a qualified small business C corporation acquired after the enactment of the Act. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gains from the sale of section 1203 stock held for over 1 year, with a limit of $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately). This applies to stock in a qualified small business C corporation acquired after the enactment of the Act, under specific conditions. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gains from the sale of section 1203 stock held for over 1 year, with a limit of $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately). This applies to stock in a qualified small business C corporation that is publicly traded on certain exchanges. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gains from the sale of section 1203 stock held for over 1 year, with a limit of $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately). A qualified small business C corporation is defined as a domestic C corporation with a market capitalization not exceeding $150,000,000 at the time of stock acquisition. Market capitalization is determined by the closing price of a share of stock on the acquisition date. The amount is determined based on the closing price of a share of stock in the corporation at the end of the reporting period before the acquisition date, multiplied by the number of outstanding shares of such stock. If this does not apply, it is determined based on the most recent amounts and all relevant facts and circumstances. The amount is determined based on the most recent amounts paid for each class of stock in the corporation outstanding on the date of the acquisition of the 1203 stock, considering all relevant facts and circumstances. The term 'reporting period' refers to the period for which the most recent annual or quarterly report is required to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires periodic information under section 15(d). Aggregation rules apply for paragraph (1). Additional rules apply, including those for qualified small business stock. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires periodic information under section 15(d). Aggregation rules apply for paragraph (1). Amendments to section 1202 reduce the holding period to 1 year. Qualified small business stock sales/exchanges under section 1202 are not counted under this section. Conforming amendments are made to sections 642(c)(4) and 643(a)(3) of the Code. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including 643(a)(3), 691(c)(4), and 871(a)(2), by inserting references to sections 1202 and 1203. Section 1044(d) is also amended to include reference to section 1203. Section 1202(b) is amended as well. Amendments are made to section 1202(b) of the Code by inserting a new subsection regarding section 1203 stock. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part 1 of subchapter P of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to securities acquired after the enactment of this Act.
